sen.j: 宍戸 （ししど たまき、文政12年3月15日 (旧暦)（1829年4月18日） - 明治34年（1901年）10月1日）は、江戸時代末期（幕末）から明治時代にかけての政治家・官僚。
sen.e: Tamaki SHISHIDO (April 18, 1829 - October 1, 1901) was a statesman and bureaucrat active from the end of the Edo period into the Meiji era.
Tamaki SHISHIDO (April 18, 1829 - October 1, 1901) was a statesman and bureaucrat active from the end of the Edo period into the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: Meiji era→Meiji periodに訂正しました。（用語統一）
sen.e: Tamaki SHISHIDO (April 18, 1829 - October 1, 1901) was a statesman and bureaucrat active from the end of the Edo period into the Meiji period.

sen.j: 子爵。
sen.e: He was a viscount.
He was a viscount.
He was a viscount.

sen.j: 前名の山県半蔵でも知られる。
sen.e: He was also known as Hanzo YAMAGATA, which was his previous name.
He was also known as Hanzo YAMAGATA, which was his previous name.
He was also known as Hanzo YAMAGATA, which was his previous name.

sen.j: 略歴
sen.e: Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History
Brief Personal History

sen.j: 文政12年（1829年）、長州藩士の安田直温の三男として生まれる。
sen.e: Tamaki was the third son of Naotsugu YASUDA, who was a feudal retainer for the Choshu clan.
Tamaki was born the third son of Naotsugu YASUDA, who was a feudal retainer of the Choshu clan in 1829.
sen.cmt: 年号と「として生まれる」の部分の訳漏れを訂正しました。a feudal retainer for the Choshu clan→forをofに訂正しました。安田直温の読み方は確認取れませんでした。
sen.e: Tamaki was born the third son of Naotsugu YASUDA, who was a feudal retainer of the Choshu clan in 1829.

sen.j: 幼名は辰之助。
sen.e: Tamaki's childhood name was Tatsunosuke.
Tamaki's childhood name was Tatsunosuke.
Tamaki's childhood name was Tatsunosuke.

sen.j: 諱は子誠、のち敬宇。
sen.e: His real name was Shisei, which was later changed to Keiu.
His real name was Shisei, which was later changed to Keiu.
His real name was Shisei, which was later changed to Keiu.

sen.j: 吉田松陰らと共に玉木文之進の塾（松下村塾）に学び、また藩校明倫館に学ぶ。
sen.e: Tamaki studied in the private school of Bunnoshin TAMAKI (Shokason-juku) together with Shoin YOSHIDA and others, and also studied in the domain school Meirinkan.
Tamaki studied in the private school of Bunnoshin TAMAKI (Shokason-juku) together with Shoin YOSHIDA and others, and also studied in the domain school Meirinkan.
Tamaki studied in the private school of Bunnoshin TAMAKI (Shokason-juku) together with Shoin YOSHIDA and others, and also studied in the domain school Meirinkan.

sen.j: 嘉永元年（1848年）藩儒の山県太華の養子となり、半蔵と称する。
sen.e: In 1848 Tamaki was adopted by Taika YAMAGATA, a Confucian scholar who worked for the domain, and called himself Hanzo.
In 1848 Tamaki was adopted by Taika YAMAGATA, a Confucian scholar who worked for the domain, and called himself Hanzo.
In 1848 Tamaki was adopted by Taika YAMAGATA, a Confucian scholar who worked for the domain, and called himself Hanzo.

sen.j: 安政元年（1854年）には江戸幕府の役人村垣範正に従い、蝦夷地および樺太・ロシア帝国巡視を行う。
sen.e: In 1854 Tamaki made a round of inspection of Ezochi (roughly corresponding to present-day Hokkaido island), Sakhalin, and the Russian Empire, accompanying Norimasa MURAGAKI: a government official in the Edo bakufu (the last feudal government headed by a shogun).

In 1854 Tamaki made a round of inspection of Ezochi (roughly corresponding to present-day Hokkaido island), Sakhalin, and the Russian Empire, accompanying Norimasa MURAGAKI: a government official in the Edo bakufu (the last feudal government headed by a shogun).

In 1854 Tamaki made a round of inspection of Ezochi (roughly corresponding to present-day Hokkaido island), Sakhalin, and the Russian Empire, accompanying Norimasa MURAGAKI: a government official in the Edo bakufu (the last feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 翌年には長崎へ遊学。
sen.e: The following year Tamaki went to Nagasaki to study.
The following year Tamaki went to Nagasaki to study.
The following year Tamaki went to Nagasaki to study.

sen.j: その頃から諸藩の志士と交流し、安政5年（1857年）藩に戻ると、明倫館都講本役に任ぜられた。
sen.e: Around that time Tamaki began to get to know men of noble ideals in many domains, and was appointed the head student in Meirinkan when he returned to the domain in 1857.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Around that time Tamaki began to get to know men of noble ideals in many domains, and was appointed the head student in Meirinkan when he returned to the domain in 1857.
Around that time Tamaki began to get to know men of noble ideals in many domains, and was appointed the head student in Meirinkan when he returned to the domain in 1857.

sen.j: 世子・毛利元徳（のち元徳）の侍講となった。
sen.e: He taught Sadahiro (later to become Motonori) MORI, who was the heir of the domain there.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処毛利元徳（のち元徳）→毛利定広（のち元徳）の誤りで、現在のWikiのページではこのように訂正されていますので、そちらにあわせて訳しました。
sen.e: He taught Sadahiro (later to become Motonori) MORI, who was the heir of the domain there.
He taught Sadahiro (later to become Motonori) MORI, who was the heir of the domain there.

sen.j: 万延元年（1860年）定広に従って江戸へ赴き国事に奔走する。
sen.e: In 1860 Tamaki followed Sadahiro to Edo and was active in national affairs.
In 1860 Tamaki followed Sadahiro to Edo and was active in national affairs.
In 1860 Tamaki followed Sadahiro to Edo and was active in national affairs.

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年）には同藩の久坂玄瑞、土佐藩の中岡慎太郎らとともに松代藩で謹慎中の学者佐久間象山を訪問。
sen.e: In 1862 Tamaki and Genzui KUSAKA who were both from the same domain, plus Shintaro NAKAOKA from the Tosa Domain, along with others, visited a scholar, Shozan SAKUMA, who had confined himself in the Matsushiro Domain.

In 1862 Tamaki and Genzui KUSAKA who were both from the same domain, plus Shintaro NAKAOKA from the Tosa Domain, along with others, visited a scholar, Shozan SAKUMA, who had confined himself in the Matsushiro Domain.
sen.cmt: plus Shintaro→スペースを詰めました。
sen.e: In 1862 Tamaki and Genzui KUSAKA who were both from the same domain, plus Shintaro NAKAOKA from the Tosa Domain, along with others, visited a scholar, Shozan SAKUMA, who had confined himself in the Matsushiro Domain.

sen.j: 長州藩へ招聘するも叶わなかった。
sen.e: They offered Shozan a post in the Choshu Domain, but it never came to fruition
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They offered Shozan a post in the Choshu Domain, but it never came to fruition
They offered Shozan a post in the Choshu Domain, but it never came to fruition

sen.j: しかし、国際情勢や国防論について薫陶を受ける。
sen.e: However they learned about the international situation and theories of national defense from Shozan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However they learned about the international situation and theories of national defense from Shozan.
However they learned about the international situation and theories of national defense from Shozan.

sen.j: 翌年帰藩した後、九州諸藩に尊王攘夷論を遊説。
sen.e: After returning to his domain the following year, Tamaki started to visit domains in the Kyushu area advocating the Sonno Joi theory (supporting reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners).

After returning to his domain the following year, Tamaki started to visit domains in the Kyushu area advocating the Sonno Joi theory (supporting reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners).

After returning to his domain the following year, Tamaki started to visit domains in the Kyushu area advocating the Sonno Joi theory (supporting reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners).

sen.j: 同年の八月十八日の政変後は京阪に潜伏して形勢を視察した。
sen.e: After the August 18 Coup of the same year, Tamaki went undercover in the Kyoto and Osaka areas to observe the situation.
After the August 18 Coup of the same year, Tamaki went undercover in the Kyoto and Osaka areas to observe the situation.
After the August 18 Coup of the same year, Tamaki went undercover in the Kyoto and Osaka areas to observe the situation.

sen.j: その後も長州藩は尊王攘夷運動に邁進するが、禁門の変の敗北、下関への四国連合艦隊襲来により窮地に陥る。
sen.e: The Choshu clan were still promoting Sonno Joi, but they ran into problems due to their defeat in the Hamaguri Rebellion (Kinmon no Hen in Japanese) and the attack on Shimonoseki by the four countries' combined fleet.

The Choshu clan were still promoting Sonno Joi, but they ran into problems due to their defeat in the Hamaguri Rebellion (Kinmon no Hen in Japanese) and the attack on Shimonoseki by the four countries' combined fleet.

The Choshu clan were still promoting Sonno Joi, but they ran into problems due to their defeat in the Hamaguri Rebellion (Kinmon no Hen in Japanese) and the attack on Shimonoseki by the four countries' combined fleet.

sen.j: 長州藩は恭順派（俗論派）の牛耳るところとなり、半蔵も禁固される。
sen.e: The allegiance faction (the conventional party) won control of the Choshu clan and consequently Hanzo was confined.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The allegiance faction (the conventional party) won control of the Choshu clan and consequently Hanzo was confined.
The allegiance faction (the conventional party) won control of the Choshu clan and consequently Hanzo was confined.

sen.j: しかし、高杉晋作・伊藤博文らの挙兵によって藩論が再転換し、赦免される。
sen.e: However Shinsaku TAKASUGI and Hirobumi ITO and others took up arms, and this changed the opinion of the clan again, resulting in Hanzo being pardoned.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However Shinsaku TAKASUGI and Hirobumi ITO and others took up arms, which changed the opinion of the clan again, resulting in Hanzo being pardoned.
However Shinsaku TAKASUGI and Hirobumi ITO and others took up arms, which changed the opinion of the clan again, resulting in Hanzo being pardoned.

sen.j: しかし幕府は長州藩へ問罪使の派遣を決定。
sen.e: However the bakufu (feudal government headed by a shogun) decided to dispatch an interrogator to the Choshu Domain.
However the bakufu (feudal government headed by a shogun) decided to dispatch an interrogator to the Choshu Domain.
However the bakufu (feudal government headed by a shogun) decided to dispatch an interrogator to the Choshu Domain.

sen.j: 同藩は山県半蔵を家老宍戸氏の養子として宍戸備後助と改名させ、広島の国泰寺 (広島市)で幕府問罪使永井尚志に応接させた。
sen.e: The Choshu clan forced Hanzo YAMAGATA to change his name to Bingonosuke SHISHIDO and become an adopted child of the SHISHIDO family (who provided the chief retainer of the domain) and made him meet Naoyuki NAGAI, the interrogator from the bakufu, in Kokutai-ji Temple in Hiroshima.

The Choshu clan forced Hanzo YAMAGATA to change his name to Bingonosuke SHISHIDO and become an adopted child of the SHISHIDO family (who provided the chief retainer of the domain) and made him meet Naoyuki NAGAI, the interrogator from the bakufu, in Kokutai-ji Temple in Hiroshima (Hiroshima City).
sen.cmt: (広島市)の訳漏れを訂正しました。
sen.e: The Choshu clan forced Hanzo YAMAGATA to change his name to Bingonosuke SHISHIDO and become an adopted child of the SHISHIDO family (who provided the chief retainer of the domain) and made him meet Naoyuki NAGAI, the interrogator from the bakufu, in Kokutai-ji Temple in Hiroshima (Hiroshima City).

sen.j: 交渉の長期化に伴い、広島藩に拘留された。
sen.e: As the negotiation took such a long time, Tamaki was taken into custody in the Hiroshima Domain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As the negotiation took such a long time, Tamaki was taken into custody in the Hiroshima Domain.
As the negotiation took such a long time, Tamaki was taken into custody in the Hiroshima Domain.

sen.j: しかし、翌年の第二次長州征伐開戦にあたり、幕府側の敗戦の調和策として放免された。
sen.e: However when the Second Conquest of Choshu occurred the following year, Tamaki was released to compensate for the defeat of the bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However when the Second Conquest of Choshu occurred the following year, Tamaki was released to compensate for the defeat of the bakufu.
However when the Second Conquest of Choshu occurred the following year, Tamaki was released to compensate for the defeat of the bakufu.

sen.j: この間の功績を認められ、宍戸家の末家を新たに建てることを認可され、直目付役に任ぜられた。
sen.e: In recognition of his achievements during the period, Tamaki was allowed to establish a new branch family of SHISHIDO and was also appointed jikimetsuke-yaku (a kind of supervisor post).
In recognition of his achievements during the period, Tamaki was allowed to establish a new branch family of SHISHIDO and was also appointed jikimetsuke-yaku (a kind of supervisor post).
In recognition of his achievements during the period, Tamaki was allowed to establish a new branch family of SHISHIDO and was also appointed jikimetsuke-yaku (a kind of supervisor post).

sen.j: 明治維新後は、明治2年（1869年）山口藩権大参事となる。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, Tamaki became "gon daisanji" (second to governor) of the Yamaguchi Domain in 1869.
After the Meiji Restoration, Tamaki became "gon daisanji" (second to governor) of the Yamaguchi Domain in 1869.
After the Meiji Restoration, Tamaki became "gon daisanji" (second to governor) of the Yamaguchi Domain in 1869.

sen.j: 翌年上京し、10月に刑部少輔。
sen.e: In October the following year Tamaki moved to Tokyo and became "gyobushoyu" (Junior Assistant Minister of Justice).
The following year Tamaki moved to Tokyo and became "gyobushoyu" (Junior Assistant Minister of Justice) in October.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせIn Octoberの位置を訂正しました。
sen.e: The following year Tamaki moved to Tokyo and became "gyobushoyu" (Junior Assistant Minister of Justice) in October.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）11月には司法大輔。
sen.e: In November 1871 Tamaki became "shiho-taifu" (a high post in the Ministry of Justice).
In November 1871 Tamaki became "shiho-taifu" (a high post in the Ministry of Justice).
In November 1871 Tamaki became "shiho-taifu" (a high post in the Ministry of Justice).

sen.j: 明治5年には文部大輔となる。
sen.e: In 1872 he became "mombu-taifu" (a high post in the Ministry of Education).
In 1872 he became "monbu-taifu" (a high post in the Ministry of Education).
In 1872 he became "monbu-taifu" (a high post in the Ministry of Education).

sen.j: 明治10年（1877年）元老院議官となる。
sen.e: In 1877 he became a councilor of the Senate.
In 1877 he became a councilor of the Senate.
In 1877 he became a councilor of the Senate.

sen.j: 明治12年（1879年）3月には清国駐剳全権公使に任命された。
sen.e: In March 1879 Tamaki was appointed the minister plenipotentiary to Qing.
In March 1879 Tamaki was appointed the minister plenipotentiary to Qing.
In March 1879 Tamaki was appointed the minister plenipotentiary to Qing.

sen.j: 琉球藩を廃止し沖縄県を設置した（沖縄県の歴史琉球処分）直後であり、琉球の帰属問題が両国間の懸案となっていた。
sen.e: This was immediately after Ryukyu Domain was abolished and Okinawa Prefecture had been established (the Ryukyu Annexation) and Ryukyu's sovereignty had become an issue between the two countries.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処外務卿→Gaimukyo (chief of Foreign Ministry)
sen.e: This was immediately after Ryukyu Domain was abolished and Okinawa Prefecture had been established (the Ryukyu Annexation) and Ryukyu's sovereignty had become an issue between the two countries.
This was immediately after Ryukyu Domain was abolished and Okinawa Prefecture had been established (the Ryukyu Annexation) and Ryukyu's sovereignty had become an issue between the two countries.

sen.j: 宍戸は琉球に対する日本の領有権の法的根拠を明記した寺島宗則・井上馨外務卿の覚書を清国総理各国事務衙門へ提出。
sen.e: SHISHIDO submitted a memorandum to the Foreign Office in Qing written by Munenori TERASHIMA and Kaoru INOUE, the foreign minister, which stipulated the legal basis of Japan's territorial right to Ryukyu
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: SHISHIDO submitted a memorandum to the Foreign Office in Qing written by Munenori TERASHIMA and Kaoru INOUE, the foreign minister, which stipulated the legal basis of Japan's territorial right to Ryukyu.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを補足しました。
sen.e: SHISHIDO submitted a memorandum to the Foreign Office in Qing written by Munenori TERASHIMA and Kaoru INOUE, the foreign minister, which stipulated the legal basis of Japan's territorial right to Ryukyu.

sen.j: 翌年交渉は妥結する。
sen.e: In the following year, the negotiations ended with agreement.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the following year, the negotiations ended with agreement.
In the following year, the negotiations ended with agreement.

sen.j: しかし清朝の重臣李鴻章らの反対により調印には至らず、明治14年（1881年）1月には交渉を打ち切って帰国した。
sen.e: However due to opposition by Li Hung Chang, senior vassal in the Qing dynasty, the agreement was not sealed and Tamaki broke off the negotiations and returned to Japan in January 1881.
However due to opposition by Hung Chang LI, senior vassal in the Qing dynasty, the agreement was not sealed and Tamaki broke off the negotiations and returned to Japan in January 1881.
sen.cmt: Li Hung Chan→Hung Chang LIに訂正しました。
sen.e: However due to opposition by Hung Chang LI, senior vassal in the Qing dynasty, the agreement was not sealed and Tamaki broke off the negotiations and returned to Japan in January 1881.

sen.j: 帰朝翌年には宮内省出仕となり、明治17年（1884年）4月には参事院議官。
sen.e: In the year following his return to Japan, Tamaki started serving the Imperial Household Ministry and in April 1884 became a member of "Sanjiin" (one of the old ministries and agencies mainly related to the executive and legislative branches).

In the year following his return to Japan, Tamaki started serving the Imperial Household Ministry and in April 1884 became a member of "Sanjiin" (one of the old ministries and agencies mainly related to the executive and legislative branches).

In the year following his return to Japan, Tamaki started serving the Imperial Household Ministry and in April 1884 became a member of "Sanjiin" (one of the old ministries and agencies mainly related to the executive and legislative branches).

sen.j: 明治18年（1885年）12月には再び元老院議官。
sen.e: In December 1885 Tamaki became a councilor of the Senate again.
In December 1885 Tamaki became a councilor of the Senate again.
In December 1885 Tamaki became a councilor of the Senate again.

sen.j: 明治20年（1887年）5月にはこれまでの功績を認められ子爵に叙爵。
sen.e: In May 1887 he was given the title of viscount in recognition of his achievement to date.
In May 1887 he was given the title of viscount in recognition of his achievement to date.
In May 1887 he was given the title of viscount in recognition of his achievement to date.

sen.j: 明治23年（1890年）帝国議会の発足に際し貴族院議員に任命され、錦鶏間祗候となる。
sen.e: In 1890, at the inauguration of the Imperial Diet, he was appointed a member of the House of Peers and became "kinkeinoma-shiko" (a title in the Imperial court).
In 1890, at the inauguration of the Imperial Diet, he was appointed a member of the House of Peers and became "kinkeinoma-shiko" (a title in the Imperial court).
In 1890, at the inauguration of the Imperial Diet, he was appointed a member of the House of Peers and became "kinkeinoma-shiko" (a title in the Imperial court).
Tamaki died in October 1901 at the age of 73.
Tamaki died in October 1901 at the age of 73.
Tamaki died in October 1901 at the age of 73.
